Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stable strontium isotope ratios (88/86Sr) in abiotic and microbially mediated barite
Award.AbstractNarration:
Results from the proposed research will generate novel isotope measurements from barite, a highly stable and widely-distributed mineral found in magmatic, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks of all ages, as well as in soils, aerosol dust, and extraterrestrial material. Establishing the controlling parameters of stable Sr-isotopic fractionation in barite will open a new avenue for geological and environmental research including geochemical, hydrogeological, hydrothermal, and paleoenvironmental studies. This fundamental research will lay the groundwork for future studies in the earth sciences using measurements of mass dependent Sr isotopes in barite. Barite may be an ideal vehicle to address critical questions in the earth sciences, including early earth biogeochemistry, evidence of potential life in extraterrestrial samples, reconstruction of temperatures in formation fluids such as springs and seeps, water rock interactions, tracking provenances of atmospheric inputs into soils, and reconstructing global changes in Sr2+ budgets during earth?s past.

Very few laboratories in the world have developed methods to measure stable Sr-isotope ratios; and work on this new stable isotopic system proposed here will provide a unique opportunity to contribute to the development of this new isotope system in its beginning stages. Graduate and undergraduate students will have the opportunity to work and interact in multiple laboratories on this research project (at Kent State Univ., USC, Univ. of Akron, UCLA, Univ. of Oklahoma) thus developing and mentoring research and analytical skills. They will conduct careful experiments, collect samples in the field at an established field site in western Oklahoma and interact with students involved in this project as well as field sites in western Colorado and northern Utah. Outreach activities in local high schools will be established through a published hands-on learning module which investigates fundamental concepts of the ?greenhouse effect? and will employ our current geology students to visit their old high schools and relay their excitement for the geosciences as a future career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The genesis of barite (BaSO4) samples is often revealed in the isotopic composition of its major and minor elements (namely sulfur, oxygen, and strontium). Until recently, only the radiogenic strontium isotopic composition was measured to differentiate between sources of strontium to form the mineral. The work supported by this project developed an improved sample preparation and analysis method, which allowed for high precision measurements of the both the stable and radiogenic strontium isotope ratios in samples with a barium-rich matrix such as barite studied here, soils, and marine sediments. This was a collaborative effort between two early-career scientists. The project produced the first, most comprehensive measurements of stable strontium isotopes in barite precipitated in the laboratory (i.e., synthetically) and sampled from relatively rare natural continental settings where barite currently precipitates.   

An understanding of the controls on stable strontium isotope ratios can be used to test theories of the mechanisms of the formation of barite in the geologic record, within ore deposits, and possibly extraterrestrial samples collected in the future. The completed work revealed controls on barite precipitated under laboratory settings that mimic modern day precipitation of barite in a continental setting in the absence of organic material. This was done to compare with samples collected from modern day continental settings with organic material and the influence of microbial activity. It is apparent from the new data set that organic material and microbial activity play a key role in barite precipitation in the continental setting and this largely controls the incorporation and partitioning of strontium (Sr) and its isotopes in barite. The variations seen in the isotopic and elemental concentrations of Sr in the natural samples are not unique, so that abiotic experiments exhibit similar variations under a range of variables including temperature and inorganic solution chemistry. Furthermore, the continental setting was found to be very dynamic when compared to other settings were barite precipitation occurs such as within the water column in open ocean settings. An extensive collection of sediment from these rare modern continental settings (warm sulfidic springs) in the continental United States where barite precipitates was gathered and archived in this project.

Additional work with another early-career scientist identified micro-scale variability in the mineralogy of one natural sample using synchrontron techniques, which is not distinguishable using traditional macroscopic analyses (like standard powder x-ray diffraction). The results were also combined with theoretical work to estimate equilibrium stable strontium isotope effects based on first principle modeling completed by a mid-career scientist with assistance from an undergraduate student.

This project supported the development and collaboration of several early career scientists, a mid-career scientist, a Ph.D. student and a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) student. Outreach activities included interactions with high school students participating in summer Upward Bound programs.
